Affine Coupling Block

nn_affine_coupling_block.Rd

An affine coupling block is a conditional flow inheriting from nn_conditional_flow() that applies the following transformation to the input.

Usage

nn_affine_coupling_block(
  input_size,
  conditioning_size = 0,
  left_size = as.integer(input_size%/%2),
  f_scale,
  f_shift,
  g_scale,
  g_shift,
  soft_clamp = 1.9
)

Arguments

input_size

The dimension of the input. The input itself is a tensor with dimensions [batch_size, input_size], or just [input_size] if there is no batch dimension.

conditioning_size

The dimension of the conditioning input, which has the same batch dimensions as the input.

left_size

The dimension of the left part of the input (the split \(x_1\) in the equations above).

f_scale

The function \(f_\text{scale}\) in the equations above. This, and the following parameters, default to a conditional multi-layer perceptron (MLP); see nn_conditional_mlp(). It must inherit from nn_conditional().

f_shift

The function \(f_\text{shift}\) in the equations above; see the above.

g_scale

The function \(g_\text{scale}\) in the equations above; see the above.

g_shift

The function \(g_\text{shift}\) in the equations above; see the above.

soft_clamp

The soft clamp value for the scale parameters.

Details

Let \(x = (x_1, x_2)\) be a split of the input into two parts, and let \(u\) be the conditioning input. The forward transformation is given by:

$$ y_1 = x_1 \exp(f_\text{scale}(x_2, u)) + f_\text{shift}(x_2, u) y_2 = x_2 \exp(g_\text{scale}(y_1, u)) + g_\text{shift}(y_1, u) $$

The inverse transformation is given by:

$$ x_1 = y_1 \exp(g_\text{scale}(y_2, u)) + g_\text{shift}(y_2, u) x_2 = y_2 \exp(f_\text{scale}(x_1, u)) + f_\text{shift}(x_1, u) $$

The log determinant of the Jacobian of the transformation is given by:

$$ \log | \det \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} | = \sum_{i=1}^2 f_\text{scale}(x_i, u) + g_\text{scale}(y_i, u) $$

By performing multiple such transformations in sequence, we can construct a complex normalizing flow capable of modeling complicated conditional distributions. Between each pair of such transformations, the dimensions of the input should be permuted using a nn_permutation_flow().

Examples

library(torch)
# Coupling block used on its own with no conditioning
flow_model <- nn_affine_coupling_block(2, 0)
x <- torch_randn(10, 2)
y <- flow_model(x)
# y will be a tensor of dimensions [10, 2]
x_recovered <- flow_model$reverse(y)
# x_recovered will be a tensor of dimensions [10, 2]
# and numerically close to the original x

# Coupling block used with conditioning
flow_model <- nn_affine_coupling_block(2, 4)
x <- torch_randn(10, 2)
u <- torch_randn(10, 4)
y <- flow_model(x, u)
# y will be a tensor of dimensions [10, 2]
x_recovered <- flow_model$reverse(y, u)
# x_recovered will be a tensor of dimensions [10, 2]
# and numerically close to the original x

# Coupling block used as part of a more complex flow model
flow_model <- nn_sequential_conditional_flow(
  nn_affine_coupling_block(2, 4),
  nn_permutation_flow(2),
  nn_affine_coupling_block(2, 4)
)
y <- flow_model(x, u)
